{{ref improve|date=February 2014}} '''Joshua Kwabena Siaw''', popularly known as '''J. K. Siaw''' (January 1923 – October 1986), was a [[Ghana]]ian [[industrialist]] and philanthropist, who in 1969 established Tata Brewery Ltd. – now known as [[Guinness Ghana Breweries]], also as Achimota Brewery Company (ABC). He is notable for opening the largest wholly African-owned brewery company in [[West Africa]] in 1973.[http://allafrica.com/stories/201504241848.html "Ghana: What Did Rawlings Know About Konadu's Acquisition Of National Assets?"] AllAfrica.com, 24 April 2015 In 1979 all his assets were confiscated by the [[Armed Forces Revolutionary Council, Ghana|AFRC]] regime of Ghana under false allegations of tax evasion. He died in [[London]], in exile, in October 1986.[http://search.ancestry.co.uk/cgi-bin/sse.dll?gl=allgs&gss=sfs28_ms_f-2_s&new=1&rank=1&msT=1&gsfn=Joshua%20Kwabena&gsln=Siaw&MSAV=0&msbdy=1923&cpxt=1&cp=11&catbucket=rstp&uidh=000 Ancestry UK, "Joshua Kwabena Siaw - Ancestry UK".] Ancestry UK, accessed 27 September 2015. ==Early life== Joshua Kwabena Siaw was born in [[Obomeng]], a small town in the [[Eastern Region (Ghana)|Eastern Region]] of Ghana, in January 1923. His father came from Akwaseho and his mother from [[Juaben]] in the [[Ashanti Region]]. J. K. Siaw worked with his father on a cocoa farm before attending school, aged 12, in 1935, and he took to basket-making as a way to make more money to further his own education.[https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Story_of_Tata.html?id=uzPUAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y ''The Story of Tata''], "a very comprehensive account of the life of Mr. Joshua Kwabena Siaw ... one of Ghana's most prominent business men". == Career == === Teacher === In 1942, aged 19, Siaw became a teacher of Standard One class in [[Akwaseho]]. After a couple of months he went to work at the Orthodox Mission School and then to the Bremang Gold Dredging Company near Bogoso, in [[Ghana]]'s Western Region. After just one month, he went to Effiduase Banko to work again as a teacher from June 1943 to March 1945. Siaw then went to work at the New Juaben Grammar School but left after a year because the headmaster, Mr. Sarkodea, was mismanaging the school. Siaw established Christ College in 1946 with his father, before apprenticing with a pharmacist for a year. Christ College evolved into Ghana Secondary School in Effiduase by 1976. === Cocoa broker === Siaw then decided to go into business and borrowed £50 (£1500.00 in 2013 relative value) to start up as a cocoa broker. In four months he had made £600 (£18,000.00 in 2013 relative value) profit. In April 1950 he became a siding clerk at Kwahu Praso, transporting cocoa to [[Accra]], Ghana's capital. He repaid the £200 security charge for the clerking employment with interest in six months and was bound for a further six months, by contract, but he decided to stay for only four. In 1953 he worked as a siding clerk, this time for the Cocoa Purchasing Company, which paid £6 a month. He became a cocoa and timber transporter in 1954. === Entrepreneur === In 1957, he began selling enamelware until the [[Government of Ghana]] under [[Kwame Nkrumah]] banned the importation of those goods. In 1964, Siaw's first request to the government to be granted permission to set up a brewery was rejected. He applied again in 1967 and that application too was rejected on the grounds that licences had been given to Ashanti and [[Takoradi]] breweries. Despite being offered an investment of 400,000 cedis from Siaw, Takoradi brewery could not happen. == Tata Brewery == A third application to the government to set up a brewery was successful and approved 26 July 1969.[http://www.annualreportsghana.com/Home/Documents/Circulars/Companies/Ghana-Breweries-(Prospectus,-Listing-by-Introducti.aspx "Ghana Breweries Propectus"], 2 July 1998. The approval was given to "Tata Trading Company" to establish a brewery in [[Cape Coast]] in the [[Central Region, Ghana]], "a place of fashion, scholarship, and beauty". A suitable site could not be found in Cape Coast and the project was relocated to Achimota, a town on the Accra-Nsawam Road.
The new National Redemption Council (NRC) government attempted to renegotiate the competing interests of the state, local businessmen, workers, and foreign capital. Loans and tax incentives were promised to Ghanaian businessmen who went into manufacturing. Tata Brewery Ltd was commissioned on 30 January 1973, Siaw's 50th birthday. It was officially opened by the then Head of State Colonel [[Ignatius Kutu Acheampong]], who said of the event: "It is the single-minded and single-handed effort of Mr. J. K. Siaw... which has been responsible for what we see around us today. Mr. Siaw is an excellent example of the innate ability of the Ghanaian to rise to the needs of the occasion". Siaw had wanted "his Brewery to stand for centuries to come", "even longer than the famous [[Osu Castle|Christiansborg Castle]]". J. K. Siaw, established Tata Brewery Limited, the first fully Ghanaian-owned brewery in the country. Tata Company secured exclusive export rights for the "Maltex" drink to neighbouring [[Togo]], Dahomey ([[Benin]]), Upper Volta ([[Burkina Faso]]), [[Ivory Coast]], [[Sierra Leone]], [[Liberia]], [[Senegal]], and [[The Gambia]] from [[Albani Brewery|Albani Breweries Limited]], a Danish firm operating in Ghana. The company was the first brewery to introduce draught beer into the country. The [[Ghana Commercial Bank]] provided a loan of 950,000 cedis for the project to begin, with a pre-requisite that Siaw deposited 200,000 cedis. By 1976, the brewery employed 750 Ghanaians and only four expatriates. Siaw produced his own brand of beer - Tata Pilsner Beer. "In the country's bid to industrialize, the alcohol industry has played a pioneering role."Emmanuel Akyeampong, "The State and Alcohol Revenues: Promoting 'Economic Development' in Gold Coast/Ghana, 1919 to the Present", ''Social History'', 1994. === Modern Continental Bank === August 25th 1977 J.K Siaw formed The Modern Continental Bank together with Mr Kwadwo Ohene-Ampofo a legal practitioner. https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qAnayU_gG68C&pg=PA1&lpg=PA1&dq=modern+continental+bank+siaw&source=bl&ots=ovJFUQcaC_&sig=aPsPqBVDNRjvzb5CRO30Pksr34k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjT_5zMuPXdAhUKIcAKHUqkD-8Q6AEwAXoECAgQAQ#v=onepage&q=modern%20continental%20bank%20siaw&f=false === Philanthropy === For the workers and their families there was a clinic, a subsidised canteen and free transport to work. Siaw sought to build housing for the workers not too far from the site. Vaccinations were provided free of charge to the workers and their families.
Siaw presented to the [[Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital]] an electro-cardiograph, a piece of equipment the hospital was deficient of.
Siaw also donated towards the construction of a hospital in Akwaseho in 1975 and begun the building of a road from Akwaseho to Obomeng,George Antwi, [http://allafrica.com/stories/200304290290.html "Ghana: J. K. Siaw Remembered"], AllAfrica, 29 April 2003. a project that ceased when the 1979 AFRC regime seized his assets.[http://www.houblon.net/spip.php?article3971 "Achimota Brewery To Return To Owners"], ''The Heritage'', 30 August 2006. No subsequent governments have completed the road.[http://www.printstatgh.com/article_detail.php?enc_id=d%2F%2BJctYajzdhUsUMqtUJ6OeORwQEVwi0Ba0mkDIl6VanmyFJlN11CmBuljFjtdyW0Tc5pjwdpl%2FeRoN%2Bv5tv3w%3D%3D "Govt urged to support Twenedurase-Akwasiho road construction"], ''[[The Ghanaian Times]]'', 1 October 2014. Siaw was the subject of a book by [[J. Benibengor Blay]] entitled ''The Story of Tata'' (c.1976).[https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Story_of_Tata.html?id=uzPUAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y ''The Story of Tata''], "a very comprehensive account of the life of Mr. Joshua Kwabena Siaw ... one of Ghana's most prominent business men". == 1979: AFRC regime == See [[Armed Forces Revolutionary Council, Ghana]] Siaw was among the businessmen targeted by the AFRC[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=48730 "Siaw's Seized Assets"], Ghana Web, 22 December 2003. under the "house cleaning" exercise against corruption. The AFRC were under the impression that Ghana's wealthiest businessmen, of whom J. K. Siaw was the most prominent, must have acquired their wealth through corruption facilitated by the country's former leaders, including Lt. Gen. [[Akwasi Afrifa]], Gen. Acheampong and Lt. Gen. [[Fred Akuffo]], who were all executed. During the short time that the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council was the government of Ghana (4 June 1979 until 24 September 1979), Siaw was arrested on numerous occasions, and his house looted.[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=24540 "'We want our brewery back' - Tata Brewery owner’s son"], GhanaWeb, 3 June 2002. Junior soldiers raided his properties for a catalogue of items, including a £3000.00 gold watch (£33000.00 in 2013 relative value),[http://www.modernghana.com/news/28865/1/how-soldiers-looted-jk-siaw.html "How soldiers looted J.K. Siaw"], ModernGhana.com, 11 December 2002. until he was released secretly by a junior soldier and left for [[Liberia]]. The tax-evasion charges totalled ¢10 million (as of 1979) however, they were false allegations. == Life in exile == === Liberia Brewery === Following from the upheaval in Ghana in 1979, Siaw started again in Liberia, which by comparison to Ghana was a very safe and peaceful country in West Africa at the time.[http://www.ghanareview.com/NEW/shownews1.php?class=all&date=2011-02-09&id=46330 "GRi Database view".] ===PNDC petitions=== Siaw petitioned the [[PNDC]] government, which came into power with the overthrow of the government of [[Hilla Limann]], who had been supported by the AFRC in the 1979 elections. The PNDC government systematically targeted businesses of other businessmen as well as Siaw.[http://www.dailyguideghana.com/?p=83475 "B. A. Mensah—-A Man Of Strength"], {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616020123/http://www.dailyguideghana.com/?p=83475 |date=16 June 2013 }} ''Daily Guide'', 24 May 2013. The National Investigation Committee, created in 1982, was created to investigate corruption in public office. It reviewed cases of persons whose assets were confiscated by the state during the three-month rule of the AFRC. The NIC "found that the confiscation of all the assets of J. K. Siaw, owner of the former Tata Brewery, on the grounds that he engaged in over-invoicing and under-invoicing during the Acheampong period was a travesty of justice".[https://books.google.com/books?id=CgFaCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA188&lpg=PA188&dq=J+K+Siaw&source=bl&ots=gozzpUginD&sig=yvuseUENgeCKLj0AztSNkgWYm2Y&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjcl4GN4dfNAhUrAcAKHUxrC_s4ChDoAQghMAI#v=onepage&q=J%20K%20Siaw&f=false "Corruption and Development in Africa: Lessons from Country Case Studies"], K. Hope, B. Chikulo. == Death == Siaw left Liberia to live in [[South London]], until he died in October 1986. He had sent numerous petitions to the military government [[PNDC]] and had applied for safe entry to be allowed back into Ghana without risk of arrest. His body was flown back to Ghana in December of that year. He did not receive his assets back and was considered a criminal by the state, despite the allegations being baseless.[http://ghanaweb.com/mobile/wap.small/news.article.php?ID=29964 "Siaw paid all taxes after all"], from ''The Ghanaian Chronicle'', 27 November 2002. ==Return of property and compensation issue== In the 1990s under the NDC government, successor to the PNDC government and AFRC, Tata Brewery (by then Achimota Brewery Company) was privatised. The [[International Finance Corporation]] provided a US$3.5 million loan and a US$1 million equity investment to help finance the US$24.5 million privatization, rehabilitation, and expansion of Achimota Brewery Company (ABC) in Accra, Ghana. The sale of the brewery by the Government of Ghana represented the largest non-mining privatization in Ghana by that time.Asimina Caminis, [http://ifcext.ifc.org/ifcext/pressroom/ifcpressroom.nsf/1f70cd9a07d692d685256ee1001cdd37/07fcb8c7fb38447d85256962004c7b09?OpenDocument PRIVATIZATION, REHABILITATION, AND EXPANSION OF GHANAIAN BREWERY FINANCED BY IFC"], International Finance Corporation. The IFC also acquired an 11% stake in the business. J. K. Siaw's family have not since received any compensation for the ordeal that they went through. --->Ghana's subsequent [[New Patriotic Party|NPP]] government announced its intention to compensate victims of the previous military regimes and return some seized assets[http://ghanaweb.net/GhanaHomePage/soccer/artikel.php?ID=110281 "PNDC, AFRC excesses and de-confiscation ..."], GhanaWeb, 8 September 2006. In 2008, the then government returned eight houses to the family[http://ama.ghanadistricts.gov.gh/?arrow=nws&read=19875 "Accra: Former heads of state to get assets"], ''Daily Graphic'', 22 October 2008. Accra Metropolitan Assembly website. on a "where is, as is basis", meaning they were made to accept the properties in the condition the government was prepared to return them. It was hinted that compensation would be paid to those whose properties were sold,[http://edition.myjoyonline.com/pages/news/200810/21696.php "Confiscated properties to be returned"], Joy Online, 16 August 2008. yet despite Tata Brewery being sold twice since confiscation[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/election2008/artikel.php?ID=243947 "Governments use de-confiscation for political expedience - Siaw"], GhanaWeb, 5 July 2012. the family received no compensation on that single property, nor on the list of items looted from Siaw's numerous properties. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Siaw, J. K.}} [[Category:Ghanaian businesspeople]] [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]]

[[Image:Jacques Balsan.jpg|thumb|right|Jacques Balsan]] '''Louis Jacques Balsan''' (September 16, 1868 – November 4, 1956) was a French aviator and industrialist, born at [[Châteauroux]] (Indre) in 1868, who was the second husband of society beauty [[Consuelo Vanderbilt]], Duchess of Marlborough. He married her immediately after her divorce from the [[9th Duke of Marlborough]] in 1921.<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
==Early life== Balsan was born on September 16, 1868 in [[Châteauroux]], [[France]]. He was the son of [[Auguste Balsan]] and Marie ([[née]] Dupuytren). Among his siblings was brother was [[Étienne Balsan]], the first patron of [[Coco Chanel]],<ref name="D'Hauterive">{{cite book |last1=D'Hauterive |first1=M. Borel |title=Annuaire De La Noblesse De France et Des Maisons Souveraines De L'Europe, Volume 44 |date=1888 |publisher=Typographie De E. Plon, Nourrit |location=[[Paris]] |page=245 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=blwoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA245&lpg=PA245 |accessdate=17 September 2018}}</ref> and sister, Viscountess Villeneuve de Bargemont of [[Davenescourt]], France.<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
Through his mother, he was descended from [[Guillaume Dupuytren]], the [[anatomist]] and [[surgery|surgeon]] who treated [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] and, today, is best known today for his description of [[Dupuytren's contracture]], which is named after him and which he first operated on in 1831 and published in ''[[The Lancet]]'' in 1834.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dupuytren|first=Guillaume|date=May 10, 1834|journal=The Lancet|title=Clinical Lectures on Surgery|volume=22|issue=558|pages=222–5|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(02)77708-8}}</ref>
Jacques Balsan came from a manufacturing family who created and run [[Balsan (Company)]] which supplied the French Army with uniforms from the time of [[Napoleon]] onwards which were the origin of the famous cloth "the blue horizon". The family's textile factories were situated at [[Châteauroux]].<ref name="1921Engagement"/>
==Career== At the age of 24, Jacques Balsan entered the family business and traveled the world, buying wool.
Passionate about ballooning, in September 1900, while in the balloon ''St. Louis'' that was inflated with [[illuminating gas]], he remained aloft for 39 hours and nine minutes.<ref name="JBObit1956"/> Later that same month, he earned the record for the highest altitude flight at the "[[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Exposition Universelle]]", by rising to a height of 8,558 meters;<ref>[http://aviation.maisons-champagne.com/dir.php?centre=04-bio-balsan&menu=11 Champagne|Berceau De L'Aviation Du Monde, Jacques Balsan]</ref> the following month traveling over 1,345 kilometers (roughly 850 miles) from [[Vincennes]] to [[Opoczno|Opoezno]], [[Russia]].<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
A pioneer of flying, he bought his first aircraft in 1905, a [[Octave_Chanute|Chanute]]-type glider, and an airplane in 1909 and obtained a Number 22 licence to pilot aircraft. He also took part in aviation experiments with the [[Wright brothers]] in [[Biarritz]] and in 1910, constructed his own small plane.<ref name="JBObit1956"/> In February 1910, in his [[Blériot Aéronautique|Blériot]] [[monoplane]], he won the "[[The meeting of Heliopolis|Le Prix d'Héliopolis]]" (in [[Egypt]]).
===Military service=== During [[World War I]], he helped organize the [[Lafayette Escadrille]] along with [[William K. Vanderbilt]] and Dr. Edmund Gros, also a founder of the [[American Hospital of Paris]] and organizer of the [[AFS Intercultural Programs#WWI|American Ambulance Field Service]].<ref name="JBObit1956"/> Later, [[Michel-Joseph Maunoury|General Maunoury]] gave him charge of the aerial [[reconnaissance]] of the site of the [[First Battle of the Marne]]. In 1918, he went to London as chief of the [[French Air Force]] mission. By the end of the War, he was promoted to the rank of [[Lieutenant colonel]].<ref name="1921Engagement"/>
During [[World War II]], he joined the [[Free French]] forces in London, taking part in the operations that liberated southern France.<ref name="JBObit1956"/>
==Personal life== [[File:JB-125-1930-Jacques & Consuelo-St Georges Motel.jpg|thumb|right|Jacques and Consuelo at [[Saint-Georges-Motel|St-Georges-Motel]], between 1930 and 1935.]] Balsan first saw and immediately fell in love with wealthy American, [[Consuelo Vanderbilt]], when she was 17, before her marriage to the 9th [[Duke of Marlborough (title)|Duke of Marlborough]].<ref name="1921Engagement">{{cite news |title=VANDERBILT TROTH REPORT IS REVIVED Marlborough Duchess's Rumored Engagement to Jacques Balsan No Surprise.HE IS FRENCH SPORTSMAN Duchess Recently Bought an Estate Near Monte Carlo—Both Are Now Among Colonists on Riviera. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/02/13/112670889.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 13, 1921}}</ref> She was considered the most eligible woman of the late [[Victorian Age]]. A memorable portrait of her by [[Carolus Duran]] hangs at [[Blenheim Palace]]. Balsan married her on 4 July 1921 (when he was 52 and she was 44), after which she was styled 'Mme Jacques Balsan',<ref name="1921OffEngage">{{cite news |title=Give Notice of Coming Marriage of Col. Balsan To Consuelo, Duchess of Marlborough |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/07/03/107018544.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 3, 1921}}</ref><ref name="1921Marriage">{{cite news |title=AMERICAN DUCHESS NOW MME, BALSAN Former Wife of Marlborough Weds French Officer in Flower-Decked London Church. {{!}} MINISTER ADDRESSES BOTH {{!}} Tells Bride "God Has Brought You at Last to Peace"—Felicitates Bridegroom. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/07/05/107019561.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 5, 1921}}</ref> until her death in 1964. Known for his attentions to her, it was a very happy marriage. Consuelo wrote to her close friend [[Winston Churchill]], during [[World War II]], while Jacques worked with the [[Free French]] in [[London]], to request his special protection and safe return. Winston obligingly facilitated his safe return to America.
The Balsans were hosting Winston and Clementine Churchill in September 1939, just before the outbreak of war at their chateau [[Saint-Georges-Motel]], near [[Dreux]] north of [[Paris]]. They also owned a property in [[Èze]] (Alpes-Maritimes) where they received a number of celebrities such as the [[Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught|Duke of Connaught]], son of Queen Victoria, The Maharajah de Kapurthala and [[Charlie Chaplin]]. <ref>{{cite book|last1=Balsan|first1=Consuelo Vanderbilt|title=The glitter and the gold|date=2011|publisher=Hodder|location=London|isbn=1444730983}}</ref> Balsan supported his wife's work with French children. They lived in their ''[[hotel particulier]]'' in Paris, 9 avenue [[Avenue_Charles-Floquet|Charles-Floquet]].
[[Consuelo Vanderbilt]]'s ghosted autobiography ''The Glitter and The Gold'' refers to her time with Balsan as "gold", as opposed to the "glitter" of her earlier, aristocratic marriage. In it, she tells the story of the Balsans' daring escape from the Nazis through Spain to Portugal and eventually to America, where they lived for the rest of their lives.<ref>Stuart, Amanda Mackenzie. ''Consuelo and Alva Vanderbilt: The Story of a Daughter and Mother in the Gilded Age''. Harper Perennial, 2005.</ref>
Jacques Balsan died on November 4, 1956 at his home, 1 Sutton Place, New York City, in America.<ref name="JBObit1956">{{cite news |title=JACQUES BALSAN, AVIATION PIONEER; French Flier Is Dead at 88-- War Pilot Set Records in Balloons and Planes Volunteer in Morocco |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1956/11/06/84944145.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1956}}</ref> His death occurred less than a month after his stepson, [[Lord Ivor Churchill]], died, at the age of 57, in London on September 17, 1956.<ref name="LordIvorObit1956">{{cite news |title=LORD IVOR CHURCHILL, 57; Patron of Modern Art, a Noted Collector, Dies in London |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1956/09/18/84714276.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 18, 1956 |language=en}}</ref> Balsan was buried in [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Newport Daily News from Newport, Rhode Island · Page 2|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/57447063/|website=Newspapers.com}}</ref> His widow died on December 6, 1964 at her home in [[Southampton, New York]] and was buried next to Lord Ivor.<ref name="CVBObit1964">{{cite news |title=Mrs. Balsan Dies; Former Vanderbilt; Mrs. Jacques Balsan, 88, Dies; Formerly Consuelo Vanderbilt |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1964/12/07/118543278.pdf |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 7, 1964 |language=en}}</ref>
==Honours==
* [[File:Legion_Honneur_Officier_ribbon.svg|50px]] Knight of the National Order of the [[Legion of Honour]] (1913 (civil) and 1925 (Officer)) * [[File:Medaille d'Outre-Mer (Coloniale) ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Colonial Medal]] (1914, Morocco) * [[File:Croix_de_Guerre_1914-1918_ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Croix de guerre 1914-1918]] (1917, with palm) * [[File:UK_Order_St-Michael_St-George_ribbon.svg|50px]] '''CMG''': [[Order of St Michael and St George|Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] (1917, United Kingdom) * [[File:Medaille_de_l'Aeronautique_ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Aeronautical Medal]] (1952, [[Santos Dumont]] promotion) * [[File:Bayon_clean.jpg|50px]] [[Commemorative medal for voluntary service in Free France]] (1946)

{{BLP sources|date=March 2015}} '''James (Jim) Champy''' (born 1942) is an American business consultant, and organizational theorist, known for his work in the field of [[business process reengineering]], business process improvement and organizational change.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
== Life and work == Champy earned his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in 1963 and his [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in civil engineering in 1965 from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], and a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from [[Boston College Law School]] in 1968.
Champy was chairman and chief executive officer of CSC Index, the management consulting arm of [[Computer Sciences Corporation]]. He had been one of the original founders of Index, a $200 million consulting practice that was acquired by CSC in 1988. Subsequently he was chairman of Dell Perot Systems’ (now Dell Services) consulting practice, where he was responsible for providing direction and guidance to the company’s team of business and management consultants.
Nowadays Champy consults with senior-level executives of multinational companies seeking to improve business performance. His approach centers on helping leaders achieve business results through four distinct, yet overlapping areas: business strategy, management and operations, organizational development and change, and information technology.
He is currently a senior research fellow at [[Harvard University Advanced Leadership Initiative|Harvard's Advanced Leadership Initiative]].<ref>{{cite web|last=James|first=Champy|title=List of Fellows|url=http://advancedleadership.harvard.edu/2013-fellows/|publisher=Harvard University - Advanced Leadership Initiative}}</ref> He is a life member of the [[MIT]] Corporation, Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Board of Trustees, and serves on the Board of Overseers of the [[Boston College Law School]]. He is also a member of the Board of Directors of [[Analog Devices, Inc]].
== Selected publications == * [[Michael Martin Hammer|Michael Hammer]], and James Champy. ''Reengineering the Corporation: Manifesto for Business Revolution,'' A. Zondervan, 1993; 2009. * Champy, James, and Lawrence Cohen. ''Reengineering management.'' Dunod, 1995. * Champy, James. ''X-engineering the corporation.'' New York, NY: Warner Books, 2002.
;Articles, a selection: * Champy, James A. "Preparing for organizational change." ''The organization of the future'' (1997): 9-16.

{{Infobox person | name = Leong Fee | image = [[File:Leong Fee - Portrait.jpg|156x156px|Leong Fee]] | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = Liang Pi Joo | birth_date = 1857 | birth_place = Guangdong Province in China | death_date = 1912 | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Tin miner, businessman, politician, philanthropist | years_active = | known_for = *He held the world record for tin production. * He was the first Chinese Member of the Federal Legislative Council. | notable_works = }} '''Leong Fee''' ({{zh|s=梁辉|zh|t=梁輝|p=Liáng Huī}}; Hakka [[Pha̍k-fa-sṳ]]: Liòng Fî) is the [[Hakka]] name for Liang Pi Joo (1857–1912), a worker from [[Guangdong Province]] in China who emigrated to [[British Malaya|Malaya]] in 1876.
==Career== He arrived in [[Penang]] and, half a year later, moved to [[Perak]] where he began to make his fortune in tin. He was a tin miner, businessman, a visiting Justice for [[Kinta District|Kinta]] (1892), the first Chinese Member of the [[Federated Malay States#Federal Council|Federal Legislative Council]] (1909)<ref>Generations: The Story of Batu Gajah By Tak Ming Ho, Perak Academy Published by HO TAK MING, 2005; {{ISBN|983-40556-5-X}}, {{ISBN|978-983-40556-5-3}}; pp. 105, 113, 117, 119, 120, 132</ref> a Penang state senator, a member of the Perak State Council, a Chinese [[Vice-Consul]] to Penang (1902 to 1908) and a philanthropist.<ref>Days Gone By: Growing Up in Penang By Christine Wu Ramsay, South Yarra: Macmillan, 2004</ref> He was a member of the Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce.<ref name="VM">[http://www.virtualmalaysia.com/destination/han%20chin%20pet%20soo.html Virtual Malaysia, The official ePortal of Tourism Malaysia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051119201139/http://www.virtualmalaysia.com/destination/han%20chin%20pet%20soo.html |date=2005-11-19 }}</ref>
In 1902 he opened a mine in [[Tambun]]. Renowned Malaysian businessman [[Leong Sin Nam]] once worked in his tin mine.<ref>Everitt, W.E. History of Mining in Perak. 1952. Vols. 14, Page 60</ref> One year later Tambun held the world record for tin production.<ref>[http://bp2.blogger.com/_OWhdrX10bSQ/RpxoiSPb-EI/AAAAAAAACK8/x6uwaBQz3NU/s1600-h/DSCN6516.jpg Ipoh Echo, July 2007]</ref>
==Leong Fee Mansion== Built on Leith Street around the 1900s as a personal residence, it now belongs to the [[Congregation of Christian Brothers|Christian Brothers]] and has been leased to an art school, Akademi Seni Equator.<ref>[http://www.pbase.com/johnglines/image/22476557 John Glines]</ref>
==Hakka Chinese Tin Miners Club== Leong Fee founded the club in Ipoh in 1893. His son, Leong Yin Khean alias Liang En-Chuen, continued to sponsor the lodge after his father's death in 1912 and eventually sold the house cheaply to the club.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> He was a member of the Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce.<ref name="VM"/>
==Personal life== He married the daughter of millionaire-philanthropist [[Hsieh Yung-kuan]], the Chinese Vice-Consul to Penang before him.<ref name="ReferenceA">The Official Website of Tourism Penang by The Penang Tourism Action Council</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Luca Garavoglia | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|02|27|df=y}} | birth_place = Milan, Italy | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Italian | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Bocconi University]] | occupation = businessman | title = Chairman, [[Campari Group]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = US$3 billion (August 2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/luca-garavoglia/ |title=Luca Garavoglia |publisher=Forbes.com |accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> | spouse = | parents = [[Rosa Anna Magno Garavoglia]] | children = | relations = | website = }}
'''Luca Garavoglia''' (born 27 February 1969) is an Italian [[billionaire]] businessman, the chairman of the [[Campari Group]].
Luca Garavoglia was born in Milan on 27 February 1969.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.rcsmediagroup.it/wp-content/uploads/doc/2014-02/CV+Luca+Garavoglia.pdf |format=PDF |title=Luca Garavoglia : CV |website=Rcsmediagroup.it |accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="insead.edu">{{cite web|url=https://events.insead.edu/alumni-forum-europe-stresa-2015/luca-garavoglia|title=Luca Garavoglia - Alumni Forum Europe |website=Events.insead.edu|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref> He was educated at Milan's [[Istituto Leone XIII]],<ref name="insead.edu"/> and received a bachelor's degree in Economics from [[Bocconi University]], Milan in 1994.<ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=8049606&privcapId=135528 |title=Stocks |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>
Garavoglia has been the chairman of [[Campari Group]] since September 1994.<ref name="bloomberg.com"/>
Following the death of his mother, [[Rosa Anna Magno Garavoglia]] on 22 November 2016, it was announced that her son Luca Garavoglia, chairman of Campari "would now assume control of Alicros, which owns 51 percent of Campari's equity, and an even greater share of voting rights".<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/campari-ownership-idUSL8N1DN5TL |title=Campari chairman takes control of main shareholder after mother dies |publisher=Reuters |date=22 November 2016 |accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>

'''Norman Oswald Cyril Marsh''' (27 July 1890 – 7 June 1973) was a British businessman in [[Ceylon]] and [[Hong Kong]]. He was also member of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]].
He served in the [[Indian Medical Service]] during the [[First World War]] in the Cavalry Branch and was promoted temporarily to Second Lieutenant in January 1915<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=29086 |date=2 March 1915 |page=2113 }}</ref> and to Lieutenant in January 1916.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=30199 |date=24 July 1917 |page=7488 }}</ref>
He was a partner at the Delmege Forsyth & Co. Ltd. in Ceylon and partner at Mackinnon, Mackenzie & Co. and general manager of the [[Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company]] in Hong Kong. He was also chairman of the [[Ceylon Chamber of Commerce]]. During his spell, he formed the Employers' Federation of Ceylon at a time when the colony was faced with labour troubles, which he brought the experience to Hong Kong to help the [[Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce]] set up the Employers' Federation of Hong Kong there.<ref>{{cite book|page=41|title=Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce Report for the Year 1947|author=Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce}}</ref> As vice chairman of the chamber of commerce, he was elected to sit as an unofficial member in the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] during the absence of [[Philip Stanley Cassidy|P. S. Cassidy]] in 1948.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce Annual Report and Accounts for 1972|author=Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce|page=37|url=https://www.chamber.org.hk/FileUpload/201102281743230136/1972_Annual_Report.pdf}}</ref> He was appointed to the Inquiry Commission on the fire of the Wing On Warehouse in [[Sai Wan]].
Marsh was a golf player and member of the [[Royal Colombo Golf Club]]. He won the 1932 Captain's Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rcgcsl.com/captains-cup|title=Royal Colombo Golf Club|work=Royal Colombo Golf Club}}</ref>

He is seen as one of the pivotal figures in the [[contemporary culture of South Korea]]. ==Biography== Oh was born in 1964 in [[Gokseong]]. He graduated from [[Yonsei University]] in 1988 with a degree in [[Korean literature]]. He earned a master's degree in journalism from [[Regent University]] in 1998 and has a PhD in mass-communication at [[Sogang University]] in [[Seoul]]. In 2006, he received the [[Wharton Infosys Business Transformation Award]] for his work with information technology, most specifically his pioneering development of OhmyNews and the society-transforming contributions that resulted. == A media career == * 1988-1999 Reporter, Chief Reporter in Monthly magazine * 1995-1997 Correspondent in Washington, DC in Monthly magazine * Feb 22th 2000 Foundation of Internet News {{Cite web|url=http://www.ohmynews.com/|title=OhmyNews|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}> CEO, The managing editor of Internet News {{Cite web|url=http://www.ohmynews.com/|title=OhmyNews|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} * 2007-2009 President of Korea Internet Newspaper Association * 2016~ Head director of Corporation 'ggumtlee' == Award winning career == * May, 2001 Awarded * Oct, 2001 Selection <55 people of South Korea> * Dec, 2001 Winning the Grand prize * Oct, 2004 Winning the Grand prize * Jan, 2006 Awarded * Oct, 2007 Awarded * OCt. 2018 Awarded ==See also== * [[Citizen journalism]] * [[Independent Media Center]] * [[Ohmynews]] == The others == * Ranked 16th in 'This year's 50s for IT characters' as UK Information Technology(IT) site (www.silicon.com{{Cite web|url=http://www.silicon.co.uk/|title=silicon.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}) (The first place-Ray Ozzie of MS, The second place-Eric Schmidt of Google) ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.ohmynews.com OhmyNews official site] * http://english.ohmynews.com/articleview/article_view.asp?no=153109&rel_no=1 * http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/2843651.stm * http://www.changemakers.net/library/temp/nytimes030603.cfm * http://www.atimes.com.by-parakeet.gibeo.net/atimes/Korea/FK25Dg01.html * http://www.wacc.org.uk/wacc/publications/media_action/253_oct_2003/ohmynews_anyone_can_be_a_reporter * Howard W. French [https://www.nytimes.com/2003/03/06/international/asia/06SEOU.html?ex=1047998393&ei=1&en=ab381a219b4f0db9 "Online Newspaper Shakes Up Korean Politics"] ''New York Times'', March 6, 2003 * http://creativeink.blogspot.com/2004/12/citizen-journalists.html * http://www.editorsweblog.org/2004/05/every_citizen_i.html {{DEFAULTSORT:Oh, Yeon-ho}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South Korean businesspeople]] [[Category:South Korean journalists]] [[Category:Regent University alumni]] [[Category:Sogang University alumni]] [[Category:Yonsei University alumni]] {{Korea-writer-stub}}

The '''Planimetría General de Madrid'''<small>{{es icon}}</small> (sometimes referred to as the '''Planimetría General de la Villa''' or the '''Visita General''') or the '''General Survey of Madrid'''<small>{{en icon}}</small> was a [[cadastral survey]] and registering of urban land carried out in the city of Madrid in the eighteenth century, between 1749 and 1759<ref name="Camarero">{{cite book|last=Camarero Bullón|first=Concepción|title=Dos catastros para Madrid a mediados del siglo XVIII: La "Planimetría General" y el "Catastro de Ensenada"|year=1989|publisher=Universidad Autónoma de Madrid|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:BSy7sg2BHDwJ:www.catastro.meh.es/documentos/publicaciones/ct/ct58/07_ct_catastro58.pdf+&hl=es&gl=es&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShdQbGudahzpbNrVAVVcb8vvExMJ1xwBsxdvwjw91uoVrRp_Jh_bjTRGvpA9PuQC0FGlQzXOkEpP4j2EAJaCNfJjQxuQPB2IFpwVvWpnuqWxQdDPEYrGxi2RY6eJ7s9tPRCl7Vl&sig=AHIEtbRMt5KfFmGFPvZqbzpuQ3mS3QygSg}}</ref> The [[cadastre]] collected information related to property ownership, size and other indications, in an effort to facilitate the imposition of the [[regalía de aposento]].<ref name=" Perellón">Francisco José Marín Perellón, (1998), Planimetría general de Madrid y visita general de casas, 1750-1751</ref>
==History== The General Survey of Madrid between 1749 and 1774 was one of the most important cadastral surveys of the Old Spanish regime. The Planimetría General de Madrid resulted in the production 557 plans of blocks throughout Madrid.<ref name=" Perellón"/>
In the cadastre documentary data were collected on the ownership of Madrid properties and other features such as previous owners, map showing the plots into which each [[City block|manzana]] or block was divided, description of the configuration and structure of each building, size and quality of the building, indication of the name and number of tenants housed per room, the tax status according to the [[regalía de aposento|aposento]] charged, among other indicators. Each block was then numbered and identified with the objective of levying taxes. This identification done by the general visit resulted in a white tile being laid on every house with writing in blue letters indicating the number assigned: "Visita G. Casa nº123" (General Visit House # 123).<ref name=" Perellón"/>
The initial intentions of the [[Zenón de Somodevilla, 1st Marqués de la Ensenada|Marqués de la Ensenada]] was to renew the tax system in [[Crown of Castile|Castile]]. Among the constraints imposed on the inhabitants of Madrid was the [[regalía de aposento]]. The method by which taxes were imposed was based on the "Visita General" which identified the nature of property ownership and assessed the taxes on inhabitants accordingly.<ref name="Camarero"/>
The imprecision of the method resulted in it being eventually abandoned. It was repealed by [[Joaquín Vizcaíno|Marqués Viudo de Pontejos]] who replaced it with a more logical which consisted of identifying streets with names of famous persons and historical events. The white numbered tiles that were laid by officials during the survey are still evidenced on the façade of Madridean houses especially in the historic center of Madrid.<ref name="Camarero"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Casas a la malicia]] * [[Regalía de aposento]]

revision.text:
'''Policy entrepreneur''' refers to an individual who takes advantage of opportunities to influence policy outcomes to increase their self-interests. The term was first coined by American [[political scientist]] [[John W. Kingdon]] in his influential work ''[[John W. Kingdon|Agendas, Alternatives and Public Policies]]'' published in 1995.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" /> Kingdon created the Multiple Streams Framework (MSF) which outlines that the policy process can be situated into problems, policy and politics. Political entrepreneurs are most active in the policy stream, creating solutions to potential problems and bringing them forth to the agenda setting process. The Multiple Streams Framework is a powerful tool to understand policy making and agenda setting. It was first created to analyze and understand agenda setting in the [[United States]].<ref name="Knaggard">{{cite journal|last1=Knaggard|first1=Å|title=The Multiple Streams Framework and the problem broker|journal=Eur J Polit Res|date=2015|issue=54|pages=450–465}}</ref> Policy entrepreneurs are the most important actors in the Multiple Streams Framework, as they develop policy alternatives and couple them with problems to present solutions to policy makers at the right time. He himself describes them as "advocates who are willing to invest their resources - time, energy, reputation, money - to promote a position in return for anticipated future gain in the form of material, purposive or solidary benefits" <ref name="KINGDONBOOK">{{cite book|last1=Kingdon|first1=John|title=Agendas, Alternatives, and Public Policies|date=2003|publisher=Pearson|location=New York, NY|edition=2nd}}</ref> Policy entrepreneurs use innovative ideas and non-traditional strategies to influence society, create opportunities, and promote desired policy outcomes. Policy entrepreneurship usually happens over three phases. It starts with a demand in the political landscape for some form of innovation involving a public good.<ref name="MintromSolo">{{cite journal|last1=Mintrom|first1=M|title=Policy Entrepreneurs and the Diffusion of Innovation|journal=American Journal of Political Science|date=1997|volume=41|issue=3|page=738|doi=10.2307/2111674}}</ref> Secondly, an innovative policy instrument is proposed to supply that demand. Lastly, strategies are used such as team building, problem definition, and leadership by example to make certain that the innovation is placed on the agenda.<ref name="MintromNorman">{{cite journal|last1=Mintrom|first1=M|last2=Norman|first2=P|title=Policy Entrepreneurship and Policy Change|journal=Policy Studies Journal|date=2009|volume=37|issue=37|pages=649–67}}</ref> Unlike a public intellect who strives to assert themselves into many different topics and be publicly vocal, a policy entrepreneur will focus on specific topics and possibly work behind the scenes with state and [[political elite]].
==Origin== The term entrepreneur is derived from the French word entreprendre, i.e. to undertake. The French economist Jean-Baptiste Say first coined the term in 1803 and defined an entrepreneur as an individual who "shifts economic resources out of an area of lower and into an area of higher productivity and greater yield". Many decades later, scholars gradually have expanded the use of the idea of entrepreneurship and adapted the concept from business to the public sector. John Kingdon (1984) was one of the earliest scholars to apply the term entrepreneurs to the public sector; he first coined the term "policy entrepreneur" in his work Agendas, Alternatives and Public Policies.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" /> This new term has been addressed in other works but hasn't been systematically used by other political scientists in theories of policy change.<ref name="MintromNorman" />
==Multiple streams framework== Kingdon’s multiple-streams framework (MSF) has been frequently used since the publication of his book Agendas, Alternatives and Public Policies in 1984.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" /> His model is an interpretation of the garbage can model of organizational choice.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cohen|first1=M. D.|last2=March|first2=J. G.|last3=Olsen|first3=J. P.|title=). Garbage can model of organizational choice|journal=Administrative Science Quarterly|date=1972|volume=17|issue=1|doi=10.2307/2392088}}</ref> In a garbage can model, organization is seen as groups of choices that seek out problems, issues and feelings that look for decisions and solutions and people willing to solve them. The multiple-streams adaption of this sees that policies can be created by joining together problems, policies and politics, all of which are seen as decision aspects in a policy process.
Government agendas are created when problems are recognized that have viable solutions that will be politically correct to make at the time of decision making.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" /> Kingdon recognizes when these three aspects join together using the term "policy window". When a policy window is recognized and open, there is a potential for policy making to happen. Policy entrepreneurs function at this time as the action takers who take advantage of these windows while they are open.<ref name="Saetren" /> In the problems stream, conditions are defined as problems based on how an individual values and believes in it and how much of an impact will happen through change. In the policy stream, ideas and solutions are formulated through policy ideas usually developed by specialists to an issue. Policy development has better chance of surviving implementation if it has support from various different communities effected by the policy. The politics stream focuses on different elements that will effect a policy such as national mood, efforts by the people to campaign for change and legislative turnover.<ref name="ZahariadisSOlo">{{cite journal|last1=Zahariadis|first1=Nikolaos|title=The Shield of Heracles: Multiple streams and the emotional endowment effect|date=November 2014|doi=10.1111/1475-6765.12072|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1475-6765.12072/full|volume=54|journal=European Journal of Political Research|pages=466–481}}</ref>
The multiple-streams framework is considered to provide the best conceptual insight in terms of the presence and influence of policy entrepreneurs and their role in emergence of policy windows<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ness|first1=Erik Christian|title=The Politics of Determining Merit Aid Eligibility Criteria: An Analysis of the Policy Process|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|date=2010|volume=81|issue=1|pages=33–60|doi=10.1353/jhe.0.0080}}</ref> by using the three 'streams' to explain the gap between a problem getting attention and the adoption of an impactful solution. Kingdon claims these are not linear processes, instead, these three streams are to be treated as separate streams, able to happen in any order. He states that these three streams must come together at the same time.<ref name="CairneyZ">{{cite journal|last1=Cairney|first1=Paul|last2=Zahariadis|first2=Nikolaos|title=Multiple streams analysis: A flexible metaphor presents an opportunity to operationalize agenda setting processes|date=2016|pages=1–21|url=https://paulcairney.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/cairney-zahariadis-multiple-streams-2016.pdf}}</ref> These streams are that a window of opportunity must exist, as well as a viable solution, combined with the motivation and the opportunity of the policy makers to select the solution. Many opportunities for policy change open, but most of them close before anyone even has a chance to take advantage because the attention of the policy agenda shifts dramatically.<ref name="CairneyZ" />
Kingdon applied this reasoning to the political system of the United States. Since policy makers do not have the time to devote to detailed policies, they give the responsibility to civil servants who consult with think tanks and interest groups to produce policy solutions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cairney|first1=Paul|title=Policy Concepts in 1000 Words: Multiple Streams Analysis|date=October 2013|url=https://paulcairney.wordpress.com/2013/10/31/policy-concepts-in-1000-words-multiple-streams-analysis/}}</ref> The likelihood of significant policy change is challenging to predict due to it requiring sustained attention, an acceptable solution, and some compromise of the political system. Building on Kingdon's work, Nikolaos Zahariadis defines it as a tool which explains how government policies are created with conditions of ambiguity.<ref name="ZahariadisSOlo" />
Since 2000, Kingdon's book has been cited over 10,000 through Google Scholar and applied in over 1,900 times in peer reviewed articles.<ref name="ZahariadisSOlo" />
==Idea to implementation==
In the multiple-streams frameworks, policy entrepreneurs do most of their work in the policy stream working on agenda setting ideas. The role of a policy entrepreneur is to first identify demand for innovation in the political landscape when a recognizable policy window is open. When this window is open, a policy entrepreneur has a limited amount of time to undergo the initial launch of proposing policy recommendations to supply the demand by utilizing their personal, network and institutional resources to take action on joining streams together on their idea through the policy stages. This is done by addressing issues and problems and coming up with solutions to them by creating policy alternatives into a product that they can present as a persuasive agenda that policy-makers should examine. They will implement persuasive strategies and techniques on the policy-makers to coerce their innovation onto the agenda. A successful policy entrepreneur will manage to get their issues onto a political agenda and potentially pass and influence a form of legislation that relates to their personal benefit. However, not every attempt will be successful. If unsuccessful, a policy entrepreneur may hold onto their agenda for a later time or even apply it to a different issue that they deem may work.<ref name="Knaggard" />
==Characteristics== These individuals have a credential that allows their opinions to be heard over others. This could be having expert knowledge on a topic or holding an important position of power in a corporation or special interest group that allows them to make decisions. A policy entrepreneur usually will have a large network of people with political influence that they utilize when pushing their idea forward. Persistence is essential for a policy entrepreneur to be successful. Many hours must be dedicated to their idea by giving speeches and talks, writing papers and speaking in front of government committees if they are to have success.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" />
Policy entrepreneurs are crucial actors in policy making, Kingdon himself explained that policy entrepreneurs are "advocates who are willing to invest their resources - time, energy, reputation, money - to promote a position in return for anticipated future gain in the form of material, purposive or solidary benefits".<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" /> Other political scientists have taken Kingdon's definition and expanded further. Michael Mintrom applied a [[Public policy|public policy perspective]] to the term stating, “they are individuals who through their creativity, strategy, networking, and persuasive argumentation are able to bring new policy ideas into the open and promote policy change".<ref name="MintromSolo" /> Years later, using a [[constructivism (international relations)|constructivist perspective]], Michael Mazarr added to this saying, “policy entrepreneurs can be seen as the human embodiment of the social construction of policy. Advocates determined, for one reason or another, to fight inertia, the bureaucracy, opposing interests, and anything else in their way to get the idea through the window [of opportunity] and into law or policy.”.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mazarr|first1=Michael|title=The Iraq War and Agenda-Setting|journal=Foreign Policy Analysis|date=2007|volume=3|issue=1|pages=1–23|doi=10.1111/j.1743-8594.2007.00039.x}}</ref>
==Reviews and criticisms== Reviews of Agendas, Alternatives, and Public Policy display mixed opinions on the approaches and concepts created by Kingdon. Roger Cobb, former professor of political science at [[Brown University]] writes in an article for the [[Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law]] that Kingdon's garbage can model approach is a completely random decision-making tool that lacks content. Cobb states that the greatest contribution of the garbage can model is the creation of new terms like policy entrepreneur that help give the sense of focus on policy problems but then argues that Kingdon himself may not fully believe in what he has created. He criticizes that Kingdon makes a legitimate arguments for structure by writing about “predictable policy windows” that are attributable to different political cycles but makes rations that would contradict his whole argument.<ref>{{cite journal|date=1985|year=|title=Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law|url=|journal=Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law|volume=10|issue=2|pages=410–414|via=|last1=Cobb|first1=Roger|doi=10.1215/03616878-10-2-410}}</ref>
Evelyn Brodkin, associate professor at [[The University of Chicago]] [[School of Social Service Administration]], writes in [[Political Science Quarterly]] that Kingdon's book provides a good analysis of how policy participants see their own role in influencing others, raising issue awareness and framing these issues for debate. She finds that his findings are beneficial for pursuing more empirical investigation and debate on different models of the agenda-setting process. In her criticism, Brodkin argues that the book fails to challenge criticisms of the pluralist theory that focus on discrepancies that illustrate how certain groups and issues systematically are excluded from the political process in which Kingdon's work is modelled on.<ref>{{cite journal|date=1985|year=|title=Political Science Quarterly|url=|journal=Political Science Quarterly|volume=100|issue=1|pages=165–166|via=|last1=Brodkin|first1=Evelyn|doi=10.2307/2150882}}</ref>
The frequent use of Kingdons agenda-setting framework in policy analysis is especially interesting because the book focuses solely on the United States. It can be argued that a framework developed exclusively on the basis of the examination of a single nation should not be able to generate useful insight in comparative research across the globe. Still, the MSF has been used in a large number of studies of subnational politics such as the European Union, the United Nations, and countries beyond the USA. Cairney and Zahariadis explain that this is because Kingdon's MSF possesses a language that is flexible enough to be relevant on a wide range of policy making processes.<ref name="CairneyZ" /> Its insights are universal enough to apply in most political systems.<ref name="CairneyZ" />
Harald Sætren, professor at [[University of Bergen]] Department of Administration and Organization Theory, writes in [[Policy Sciences]] that one of the problems with the multiple-streams framework is that differing methods of finding issues and solutions potentially can effect how successful a policy entrepreneur can be in coupling policy streams.<ref name="Saetren">{{cite journal|last1=Sætren|first1=Harald|title=From controversial policy idea to successful program implementation: the role of the policy entrepreneur, manipulation strategy, program design, institutions and open policy windows in relocating Norwegian central agencies|journal=Policy Sciences|date=2016|volume=49|issue=1|pages=71–88|doi=10.1007/s11077-016-9242-4}}</ref>
==Policy entrepreneurs==
As of 2017, "policy entrepreneur" is not a recognized job position. John Kingdon's research consisted of case studies on 23 different people he deemed to be policy entrepreneurs.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" /> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name !! Position !! Policy Accomplishments |- | [[Paul Ellwood]] || Head of Interstudy || Promoted the [[HMO|HMO legislation]] |- | Abe Bergman || [[Physician]] || Persuaded Senator [[Warren Magnuson]] on the positives of having a Health Service Corps, which funded research on sudden infant death syndrome. Helped legislate the regulation of flammable children's sleepwear. |- | [[Ralph Nader]] || [[Advocate|Consumer Advocate]] || Began successful career pushing ideas about auto safety issues. |- | [[Pete Domenici]] || [[Senator]] || Responsible for pushing a waterway user charge. |- | [[Alfred E. Kahn|Alfred Kahn]] || [[Economist]], [[Civil Aeronautics Board|Head of Civil Aeronautics Board]] in the [[Carter Administration]] ||Used political influence to implement legislation and regulation safety for airlines |}.<ref name="KINGDONBOOK" />
[[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] is a mechanical engineer that engaged in the debate about whether paddle wheels or screw propellors were more powerful for moving boats. He tested this by building one of each and using them in a channel to see which would tug the hardest. The point of his story is that he was engaged on the ground and not just researching in a lab. Policy entrepreneurs need to be practically involved in testing their theories if they want their recommendations to be considered <ref>{{cite web|title=Isambard Kingdom Brunel|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/primaryhistory/famouspeople/isambard_kingdom_brunel/|website=Primary History|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
In a study done by [[Mark Beeson]] and Diane Stone, [[Ross Garnaut]] was examined in a role of a policy entrepreneur. Garnaut was a highly decorated scholar, recognized economist who was also an ambassador to China and a prime ministerial advisor in Australia. In his role as advisor to [[Bob Hawke|Prime Minister Hawke]], he wrote to him about problems with fixed exchange rates and instituting labour-market reform. The government went on to implement a radical program of economic liberalisation that included addressing some of the issues Garnaut consulted on.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Beeson|first1=M|last2=Stone|first2=D|title=The Changing Fortunes of a Policy Entrepreneur: The Case of Ross Garnaut|journal=Australian Journal of Political Science, 48(1), 1-14.|date=2013|volume=48|issue=1|pages=1–14|doi=10.1080/10361146.2012.760526}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Political entrepreneur]] *[[Politician]] *[[Social entrepreneur]] *[[Agenda-setting theory]] *[[Lobbyist]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
Cohen, Nissim (2016) “[https://books.google.co.il/books?hl=en&lr=lang_en&id=n4EwDQAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA180&ots=LGDc5_Un7i&sig=G-xzQnwoLapiTATkYMI7qyJGo_8&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false Policy Entrepreneurs and Agenda Setting]”. In Zahariadis, Nikolaos (ed.), Handbook of Public Policy Agenda Setting. Edward Elgar, pp. 180–199.
Cohen, Nissim (2012) “[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=ZGVmYXVsdGRvbWFpbnxqcnNwb25lfGd4OjVkMGQ2ODZkZTNmZWY4MTM Policy Entrepreneurs and the Design of Public Policy: Conceptual framework and the Case of the National Health Insurance Law in Israel]” Journal of Social Research & Policy, 3 (1): 5-26.

{{Infobox scientist |name= Robert Edward Freeman |image= |caption= |birth_date= {{birth date|1951|12|18|mf=y}} |birth_place= [[Columbus, Georgia]], United States |fields=American Philosopher and Professor of Business Administration | workplaces = Elis and Signe Olsson Professor of Business Administration at [[Darden School of Business]], [[University of Virginia]] |alma_mater= [[Wharton School]] of the [[University of Pennsylvania]] |dead=No }}
'''R. Edward Freeman''' (born December 18, 1951) is an [[United States|American]] [[philosopher]] and [[professor]] of [[business administration]] at the [[Darden School]] of the [[University of Virginia]], particularly known for his work on [[stakeholder theory]] (1984) and on business works.
== Biography == Born in [[Columbus, Georgia]], Freeman received a B.A. in [[mathematics]] and [[philosophy]] from [[Duke University]] in 1973 and a Ph.D. in [[philosophy]] from [[Washington University]] in 1978.
He taught at the [[University of Minnesota]] and the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School]], and is now Elis and Signe Olsson Professor of Business Administration at the Darden School of the University of Virginia. He is also academic director of the Business Roundtable Institute for Corporate Ethics, and director of the Darden's Olsson Center for Applied Ethics.<ref name="F-CV 84">[http://www.csrhellas.org/portal/images/stories/files/1984_Freeman_CV.pdf Freeman's curriculum vitae]. Accessed Feb 27, 2013.</ref> In 1994 Freeman served as president of the [[Society for Business Ethics]]. He is one of the executive editors of the journal [[Philosophy of Management]] and he serves as the editor for the Ruffin Series in Business Ethics from [[Oxford University Press]].
In 2001 Freeman was awarded the Pioneer Award for Lifetime Achievement by the [[World Resources Institute]] and by the [[Aspen Institute]], and in 2005 the Virginia State Council on Higher Education honored him with the Outstanding Faculty Award.
== Work == Freeman is particularly known for his work on [[stakeholder theory]] originally published in his 1984 book ''Strategic Management: A Stakeholder Approach''. He has (co)authored other books on corporate strategy and business ethics. Also recently he co-edited standard business textbooks such as ''The Portable MBA'' and the ''Blackwell's Handbook of Strategic Management.'' His latest book, ''Managing for Stakeholders'', was published 2007.
=== Stakeholder theory === [[Stakeholder theory]] is a theory of organizational management and [[business ethics]] that addresses morals and values in managing an organization. It was originally detailed by Freeman in the book ''Strategic Management: a Stakeholder Approach'', and identifies and models the groups which are [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]]s of a [[corporation]], and both describes and recommends methods by which management can give due regard to the interests of those groups. In short, it attempts to address the "Principle of Who or What Really Counts."<ref name="REF 84">{{cite book |title=Strategic Management: a stakeholder approach |last=Freeman |first=R. Edward |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1984 |publisher=Pitman |location=Boston |isbn=0-273-01913-9 |pages= }}</ref>
In the traditional view of the firm, the [[shareholder]] view, the shareholders or stockholders are the owners of the company, and the firm has a binding [[fiduciary]] duty to put their needs first, to increase value for them. However, stakeholder theory argues that there are other parties involved, including [[Government agency|governmental bodies]], [[political group]]s, [[trade association]]s, [[trade unions]], [[community|communities]], [[financier]]s, suppliers, [[employee]]s, and [[customer]]s. Sometimes even competitors are counted as stakeholders - their status being derived from their capacity to affect the firm and its other morally legitimate stakeholders. The nature of what is a stakeholder is highly contested (Miles, 2012),<ref>{{cite journal|last=Miles|first=Samantha|title=Stakeholders: essentially contested or just confused?|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2012|volume=108|issue=3|pages=285–298|doi=10.1007/s10551-011-1090-8}}</ref> with several definitions existing in the academic literature (Miles, 2011).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Miles|first=Samantha|title=Stakeholder Definitions: Profusion and Confusion|journal=EIASM 1st interdisciplinary conference on stakeholder, resources and value creation, IESE Business School, University of Navarra, Barcelona|year=2011}}</ref>
=== Corporate social responsibility === [[Corporate social responsibility]] (CSR) <ref>D Wood, 'Corporate Social Performance Revisited' (1991) [https://www.jstor.org/stable/258977 16(4) The Academy of Management Review]</ref> is a form of [[corporate]] [[Industry self-regulation|self-regulation]] integrated into a [[business model]]. CSR policy functions as a built-in, self-regulating mechanism whereby a business monitors and ensures its active compliance within the spirit of the law, ethical standards, and international [[norm (sociology)|norm]]s. CSR is a process with the aim to embrace responsibility for the company's actions and encourage a positive impact through its activities on the environment, consumers, employees, communities, [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] and all other members of the [[public sphere]] who may also be considered as stakeholders.
The term "corporate social responsibility" came into common use in the late 1960s and early 1970s after many multinational corporations formed the term [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]], meaning those on whom an organization's activities have an impact. It was used to describe corporate owners beyond [[shareholders]] as a result of an influential book by Freeman, ''Strategic management: a stakeholder approach'' in 1984.<ref name="REF 84"/> Proponents argue that corporations make more long term profits by operating with a perspective, while critics argue that CSR distracts from the economic role of businesses. Others argue CSR is merely [[Display window|window-dressing]], or an attempt to pre-empt the role of governments as a watchdog over powerful [[multinational corporations]]. Anticipation of such concepts appear in a publication that appeared in 1968 <ref>"Integrated structures in the Italian distribution system," Giuffre Editore, Milan, 1968, pp. VIII / 351</ref> by Italian economist Giancarlo Pallavicini, creator of the "Method of the decomposition of the parameters" for the calculation of the results does not directly cost of business, regarding ethical issues, moral, social, cultural and environmental.<ref>"Universal Biographical Encyclopedia" Treccani, 2007 edition, Vol. 14, p. 617; "Treccani - Portal", Social sciences / economics / Biographies; Bancoper Annual Meeting, Bologna, 15.11.2008, Prefect Angelo Tranfaglia, "Profit and Social Responsibility", p. 12; "Finanza e Mercati", 3 February 2009, p. 11, Mara Consoli, "When ethics becomes a bargain"; News Chronicles, CNEL, Rome, 12.01.2009, Adelaide Mochi, "Socialis Awards and Corporate Social Responsibility"</ref>

{{Infobox criminal | name = Radovan Krejčíř | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|11|4}} | birth_place = [[Dolní Žukov]], [[Czechoslovakia]] (now [[Czech Republic]]){{cite web|url=http://tema.novinky.cz/radovan-krejcir|title=Radovan Krejčíř|last=Fiala|first=Luděk |author2=Trousilová, Alžběta |publisher=[[novinky.cz]]|language=Czech|accessdate=25 November 2013}} | other_names = Egbert Jules Savy | nationality = Czech | conviction = [[Fraud]], attempted murder of Czech government official, attempted [[bribery]], [[Counterfeit money|money counterfeiting]] | alma_mater = [[Technical University of Ostrava]] | wanted_by = [[Government of the Czech Republic]] | conviction_status = 15.5 years in the Czech Republic
35 years in South Africa | imprisoned = [[Pretoria Central Prison|Kgosi Mampuru Prison]], South Africa | charge = [[Fraud]], [[kidnapping]], attempted murder, conspiracy to commit murder, [[murder]], [[Racket (crime)|racketeering]] }} '''Radovan Krejčíř''' (born 4 November 1968) is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] former [[organized crime]] boss and convicted criminal who is serving a prison term in [[South Africa]] and is being sought for [[extradition]] by the [[Government of the Czech Republic|Czech government]]. He has been sentenced to 15.5 years in the Czech Republic and 35 years in South Africa.{{Cite web|url=https://zpravy.idnes.cz/radovan-krejcir-soud-vydani-do-ceske-republiky-fle-/zahranicni.aspx?c=A180317_125120_zahranicni_ert|title=Radovan Krejčíř může být vydán do Česka, rozhodl jihoafrický soud|date=2018-03-17|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-03-25}} He became rich through criminal activity during the 1990s and was considered one of the richest people in the [[Czech Republic]]. Krejčíř fled from the country shortly after being arrested in June 2005 and resided in the [[Seychelles]].{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Krejcir-scoffs-at-Mafia-boss-claims-20100829|title=Krejcir scoffs at 'Mafia boss' claims|last=Rademeyer|first=Julian|date=29 August 2010|publisher=[[News24]]|accessdate=25 November 2013}} In 2012, he was sentenced [[Trial in absentia#Czech Republic|in absentia]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25088134|title=Radovan Krejcir: Czech man 'beaten by South African police'|date=25 November 2013|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=26 November 2013}} to eight years of imprisonment for fraud totalling [[CZK]] 108,000,000.{{cite web|url=http://zpravy.ihned.cz/cesko/c1-55956800-krejcir-musi-za-zproneveru-108-milionu-na-8-let-do-vezeni-potvrdil-odvolaci-soud|title=Krejčíř musí za zpronevěru 108 milionů na 8 let do vězení, potvrdil odvolací soud|date=28 May 2012|work=[[Hospodářské noviny]]|publisher=iHNED|language=Czech|accessdate=25 November 2013}} In November, 2013, he was arrested and charged with kidnapping and attempted murder in South Africa.{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-11-25-krejcir-wins-urgent-application-off-to-hospital|title=Court sends Krejcir to hospital|date=25 November 2013|publisher=[[Mail & Guardian]]|accessdate=25 November 2013}} The trial started in May 2014.http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Krejcir-trial-starts-20140508 In August 2015, he was found guilty of attempted murder, assault and kidnapping, among other things. Other trials are still in progress. In Johannesburg, on 23 February 2016, Radovan Krejčíř has been sentenced to 35-years in jail. http://zpravy.aktualne.cz/zahranici/vinen-jihoafricky-soud-vynesl-prvni-rozsudek-nad-krejcirem/r~67c3deb24a4911e5b286002590604f2e/ == Biography == His criminal activities began in the early 1990s, following the [[Velvet Revolution]]. He co-founded the company Corado and amassed great wealth during the Czech [[voucher privatization]]. His activities and companies were monitored by the police since the mid-1990s, due to suspicion of illegal money transfers. In June 2005, the police raided his luxury villa in [[Černošice]] and arrested him in association with a planned murder of a [[customs officer]], fraud and criminal conspiracy. Krejčíř fled the house during the police intervention,{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-11-22/s-africa-charges-czech-fugitive-krejcir-with-attempted-murder.html|title=S. Africa Charges Czech Fugitive Krejcir With Attempted Murder|last=Sguazzin|first=Antony |date=22 November 2013|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=25 November 2013}} which later led to the resignation of the [[Police of the Czech Republic|Czech Police]] President Jiří Kolář.{{cite web|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/news-2005-09-22|title=Government appoints new police president |last=Velinger|first=Jan |date=22 September 2005 |publisher=[[Czech Radio]]|accessdate=25 November 2013}} In September, 2005, [[Interpol]] traced him and his family in the Seychelles. In April 2007, he moved to South Africa under the false name Egbert Jules Savy.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/failed-hitman-james-bond-style-gun-attack-article-1.1409600|title=Failed hitman uses James Bond-style machine gun hidden behind license plate|last=Beekman|first=Daniel|author2=Moran, Lee |date=26 July 2013|publisher=[[The New York Daily News]]|accessdate=25 November 2013}} He was arrested and taken into custody at [[O. R. Tambo International Airport]] in [[Johannesburg]]. The Czech Republic started negotiations about his [[extradition]] with the South African authorities, however, South Africa did not allow the extradition, as it was alleged he had paid bribes to the necessary judge. He is wanted for tax fraud and conspiracy to murder in the Czech Republic. In South Africa, Krejčíř established contacts with the local criminal scene.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/article988999.ece/Krejcir--four-years-of-murder-sleaze-and-mayhem|title=Krejcir: four years of murder, sleaze and mayhem|last=Swart|first=Werner|author2=Pather, Sashni |date=21 April 2011|publisher=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]]|accessdate=25 November 2013}} He himself became a target of an attack in July 2013, when his car was hit by a remote-control gun. He figured in the murder investigation of crime boss Cyril Beeka, who was killed in [[Cape Town]] in 2011. The South African media associate him with several other murders in the local underworld,{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-11-13-fdsfsd|title=How bodies have piled up around Radovan Krejcir|date=13 November 2013|publisher=Mail & Guardian|accessdate=25 November 2013}} and also the luring, abduction and murder of Stuttgart-based [[Gemballa]] automobile tuning factory's founder Uwe Gemballa.{{Cite web|url=https://www.autoblog.com/2010/10/13/followup-did-uwe-gemballa-die-because-of-a-money-laundering-sch/|title=Followup: Did Uwe Gemballa die because of a money laundering scheme?|website=Autoblog|access-date=2017-09-02}}{{Cite news|url=http://jalopnik.com/police-arrest-man-connected-to-porsche-tuner-uwe-gembal-1469785138|title=Police Arrest Man Connected To Porsche Tuner Uwe Gemballa's Murder|last=Hardigree|first=Matt|work=Jalopnik|access-date=2017-09-02|language=en-US}} According to one report, Krejčíř was allegedly bringing money into South Africa in Gemballa cars.{{Cite web|url=https://www.autoblog.com/2010/10/13/followup-did-uwe-gemballa-die-because-of-a-money-laundering-sch/|title=Followup: Did Uwe Gemballa die because of a money laundering scheme?|website=Autoblog|access-date=2017-09-02}} Krejčíř was convicted for drug dealing{{cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/convicted-drug-dealer-krejcir-and-co-back-in-court-for-murder-20170509 |title=Convicted drug dealer Krejcir and co back in court for murder |newspaper=News24 |date=9 May 2017 |first=Iavan |last=Pijoos}} and serves his sentence in Gauteng's [[Pretoria Central Prison|Kgosi Mampuru Prison]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/video-shows-oscar-pistorius-playing-football-with-ex-mafia-boss-radovan-krejcir-10102094.html |title=Video ‘shows Oscar Pistorius playing football with ex-mafia boss Radovan Krejcir’ |first=Kashmira |last=Gander |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=11 March 2015}} On 31 March 2017, his Seychellois citizenship was revoked.http://www.statehouse.gov.sc/news.php?news_id=3387 == Attempted prison escape == A number of illegal items were discovered on 26 September 2015 in an apparent raid of a number of prison cells including that of Krejčíř. Amongst the items found were a pistol, ammunition, a knife, an item that appeared to be a [[Taser]], a [[pepper spray]] gun, screwdriver steel blade, ten cellphones, a memory stick, a diary which contained the names of witnesses and investigators in his cases and a sketch showing a detailed map of the prison building. The escape was to take place at his next court appearance in October 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Krejcir-escape-plan-foiled-20150927|title=Krejcir 'escape plan' foiled|date=29 September 2015|publisher=Media24}} It was revealed that a staggering R246 million ($18 million USD) had been made available to ensure the smooth escape of Krejčíř from prison. Three prison warders were paid R1.5 million to help expedite the prison break. Impeccable sources close to the investigation revealed that the three warders have already been identified and their arrest is imminent. Krejčíř has been moved to an underground isolation cell after it has been established that a helicopter was going to be used in the daring raid to free him. Some of the R246 million was used to pay for this helicopter to spirit Krejčíř away once he had escaped. A part of the money was also to be used to pay all the people, including the police, who were involved in the plan to spring him out of jail and some would have been used to pay for the landing rights for a chartered plane to fly him out of the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/sundayindependent/r246m-for-krejcir-jailbreak-1.1924623#.VhKAZHqqqko|title=R246m for Krejcir jailbreak|date=4 October 2015|publisher=Sunday Independent}} [[Judge]] of Tribunal in [[Johannesburg]] Colin Lamont, condemned him on 23 February, 2016 to 35 years in jail. ==In popular culture== [[Gangster Ka]] a Czech film directed by Jan Pachl, is inspired by the story of Radovan Krejčíř. The movie premiered in 2015. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Krejcir, Radovan}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Czech businesspeople]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted by the Czech Republic]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:People from Český Těšín]] [[Category:Czech mob bosses]] [[Category:Czech prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of South Africa]]

({{age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=6|day1=4|year1=1989|month2=12|day2=26|year2 =1991}}) |place=[[Central and Eastern Europe]] |coordinates= |causes= * [[Political repression]] * [[Authoritarianism]] * [[Religious persecution]] * Severe [[economic crisis]] * [[Consumerism|Consumerist]] pressure{{cite book|last1=Kochanowicz|first1=Jacek|editor1-last=Berend|editor1-first=Ivan T.|editor1-link=Iván T. Berend|title=Backwardness and Modernization: Poland and Eastern Europe in the 16th-20th Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f6RGpe1mjzQC|series=Collected studies: Studies in East-Central Europe|volume=858li|location=Aldershot|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|publication-date=2006|page=198|isbn=9780754659051|accessdate=14 November 2017|quote=Within the communist world, certain strata of population were particularly sensitive to Western influences. Late communism produced sizable, specific middle classes of relatively well-educated professionals, technicians and even highly skilled blue-collar workers. Many members of the ruling 'nomenklatura' shared the same sentiments, as Western consumerism and individualism seemed more attractive to them than communist collective Puritanism. There were two very important consequences of this, one economic, and the second political. The economic one was the attractiveness of consumerism [...]. The political consequence was the pressure to increase the margins of political freedom and public space.}}{{cite book|last1=Cross|first1=Gary S.|chapter=1: The Irony of the Century|title=An All-consuming Century: Why Commercialism Won in Modern America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xc1fNOhoZvkC|location=New York|publisher=Columbia University Press|publication-date=2000|page=8|isbn=9780231113120|accessdate=14 November 2017|quote=For East Europeans, the promise of mass consumption was preferable to the nightmare of solidarity even if it meant also the dominance of money and the private control of wealth. In reality, the fall of communism had more to do with the appeals of capitalist consumerism than political democracy.}} |goals= * Economic reforms including [[privatisation]] of state-owned industry * [[Democracy]] * [[Civil liberty]] * [[Self-determination|National self-determination]] * [[Free and fair elections]] * [[Recall election|Right to recall of elected officials]] * [[Political freedom]]s * [[Labour rights]] * [[Human rights]] * [[Open borders]] * [[Free markets]] |methods=[[Mass protest]]s

BBC News. Retrieved 11 March 2007. * Formation of the [[Russian Federation]] and [[Post-Soviet states|14 other states]] from the former Soviet Union * Dismantling of the [[command economies]] and Democratic Republic of Ethiopia#Failures and collapse|Ethiopia]], [[People's Republic of Mozambique|Mozambique]], [[Somali Rebellion|Somalia]] and [[South Yemen#Reforms and attempts for
